stats.name: pH
stats.description: Measures the acidity of your water and should be between 6 and 9 pH units. A lower pH causes pipes to corrode which contaminates your water with lead and copper. A higher pH causes skin irritation.

stats.name: Fluoride
stats.description: In amounts less than 2 ppm, Fluoride protects your teeth against cavities and prevents tooth decay. A higher amount of fluoride can cause enamel fluorosis (severe teeth staining).

stats.name: Hardness
stats.description: Measures the amount of Calcium and Magnesium in your water. Your water is hard if it’s above 120 ppm and soft if it’s below 120 ppm.

stats.name: Turbidity
stats.description: Measures the clarity of your water. Clear water has low turbidity and cloudy/murky water has a higher turbidity level.

stats.name: Chlorine
stats.description: A disinfectant used to protect your water against waterborne diseases. Your water should have between 2 ppm and 4 ppm of chlorine to ensure that it is safe to drink.

stats.name: Lead
stats.description: A very toxic metal that can cause severe health problems like brain and kidney damage. Lead contamination is usually caused by pipe corrosion. If your water has more than 15 ppb of lead, it is NOT safe to drink!

stats.name: Copper
stats.description: A very toxic metal that can cause severe health problems like liver and kidney disease. Copper contamination is usually caused by pipe corrosion. If your water has more than 1.3 ppm of copper, it will taste metallic and it is NOT safe to drink!

stats.name: Trihalomethanes
stats.description: Measures the amount of disinfectant by-products in your water. At levels above 80 ppb, Trihalomethanes can be carcinogenic and also affect pregnant women.

stats.name: Sodium
stats.description: In amounts less than 30 ppm, Sodium is harmless. A greater amount of Sodium can affect the taste of your water. It can also be harmful to people with high blood pressure and dialysis patients.

stats.name: Nitrates
stats.description: Measures the amount of nitrogen-based compounds in your water. Nitrate levels greater than 10 ppm can be harmful for pregnant women and babies.
